awd_titl_txt: RUI:  Cellular and Biochemical Mechanisms of Allelochemical Toxicity of L-azetidine-2-carboxylic Acid to Helicoverpa    zea
awd_abstract_narration: Insect herbivores are confronted with a formidable and diverse                  array of naturally occurring plant toxins.  We have shown that the              corn earworm, Helicoverpa zea (Boddie), a polyphagous insect, is                highly sensitive to the antimetabolic effects of 1-azetidene-2-                 carboxylic acid (AZC), a naturally occurring higher plant homolog               of proline.  Larvae reared on a diet containing AZC suffer                      developmental retardation and exhibit various developmental                     lesions.  AZC toxicity is typically expressed during larval molts               and it is particularly evident at the larval-pupal molt.  If                    larval-pupal ecdysis occurs, the pupae are frequently deformed;                 often exhibiting large, nonsclerotized areas.  The cellular and                 biochemical mechanisms for the toxicity of AZC and many                         allelochemicals are largely unknown.  This study of the cell /                  tissue morphological and biochemical events that precede and / or               accompany the symptoms of AZC toxins in H. zea will increase                    understanding of the protective role of allelochemicals in                      plant-herbivore interactions, and has the potential to further                  development of insect pest controls which do not require industrial             pesticides.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: DUQUESNE UNIVERSITY OF THE HOLY SPIRIT
